title: Cat. 26 Portrait of Miss Maud Franklin, 1883/88
publication_title: Whistler Paintings and Drawings at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone"> Stephanie L. StrotherPortrait of Miss Maud Franklin, 1883/88  
Pen and brown ink on cream laid paper; 17.8 × 11.4 cm (7 × 4 1/2 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Walter S. Brewster, 1933.298

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Maud Franklin modeled frequently for James McNeill Whistler over a period of roughly fifteen years, beginning in the mid-1870s. For much of that time she was also his live-in romantic partner, caring for him and managing his affairs while tirelessly posing for his work in every medium. She was a devoted model, capable of withstanding the grueling and interminable sessions Whistler’s meticulous process demanded. Charming and refined, she was once described by the writer and art critic Théodore Duret as having the air of a “woman of the world (dame du monde),” and it is precisely this attitude of confident sophistication that animates the figure in the Art Institute drawing. Whistler’s pen dances over Franklin’s graceful form, capturing her vivacious spirit with bold and lively strokes. The artist’s hand is seen here at its most confident, distilling the image to a minimum of line and shading without sacrificing legibility. As is often the case in Whistler’s drawings, prints, and paintings of Franklin, she appears slim and elegant, her sophisticated bearing embodying the very characteristics that distinguish Whistler’s artistic style.

Franklin is shown here from the back, her face turned in profile. This angle draws attention to the fashionable silhouette of her dress, with its puffed shoulders and form-hugging fit. A few wavy lines serve to indicate flounced fabric pulled over the prominent bustle. Whistler often exploited this vantage point to accentuate details of costume in his portraits of chic women (see Study for “Arrangement in Black, No. 2: Portrait of Mrs. Louis Huth” [recto]; Study for “Symphony in Flesh Color and Pink: Portrait of Mrs. Frances Leyland” [verso], cat. 14; and Sketch after “Arrangement in Brown and Black: Portrait of Miss Rosa Corder,” cat. 20), and depicted Franklin in a similar attitude on several occasions (see Maud, Standing, fig. 26.1, [K 144]; and The Toilet, fig. 26.2, [Way 6]). Franklin also strikes a comparable pose in a rare photograph (fig. 26.3), calling to mind the contemporary fashion plates that provided compelling source material for style-conscious artists such as Whistler (fig. 26.4). While, as Margaret MacDonald points out, it is impossible to know whether Franklin selected her own outfits or whether they were dictated by Whistler, they consistently reflect an unfussy, sophisticated good taste.

Franklin was herself an artist, exhibiting her work under the pseudonym Clifton Lin at both the Grosvenor Gallery and the Society of British Artists in London around the time Whistler made the drawing of her. Though almost no examples of her work survive, the titles of those exhibited suggest that she favored still lifes of flowers and figure studies as subjects. The end of Franklin’s tenure as an exhibiting artist corresponded with the abrupt termination of her relationship with Whistler in 1888, when he married another artist, Beatrice Godwin. Franklin also eventually married, first the New Yorker John A. Little, then another New Yorker, Richard H. S. Abbott. She refused to speak about Whistler when his biographers sought her out in later years. Despite the tumultuous end of their relationship, her enduring mark on Whistler’s life and the lives of those closest to him is attested by the fact that the present drawing was owned by Whistler’s son, Charles James Whistler Hanson, until 1924. Though Whistler and Franklin’s artistic collaboration ultimately proved impermanent, its imprint on Whistler’s oeuvre is also indelible. His many images of Franklin bespeak a remarkably productive partnership, artist and model united in their commitment to furthering a shared aesthetic vision.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Portrait of Miss Maud Franklin corresponds to Margaret F. MacDonald, James McNeill Whistler: Drawings, Pastels, and Watercolours; A Catalogue Raisonné (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 1995), hereafter MacDonald (1995), cat. 896. View M 896 online at Margaret F. MacDonald and Grischka Petri, James McNeill Whistler: The Paintings; A Catalogue Raisonné (Glasgow, UK: University of Glasgow, 2014), hereafter MacDonald and Petri.

For contemporary commentary on Maud Franklin’s relationship with Whistler, both as model and companion, see E. R. and J. Pennell, The Whistler Journal (Philadelphia: J. B. Lippincott, 1921), 163–66; and T. R. Way, Memories of James McNeill Whistler, the Artist (London: John Lane, 1912), 15. For modern scholarly perspectives, see Margaret F. MacDonald, “Maud Franklin,” Studies in the History of Art 19, Symposium Papers VI: James McNeill Whistler: A Reexamination (1987): 13–26; Margaret F. MacDonald, “Franklin, Maud (British, 1857–c. 1941),” in Dictionary of Artists’ Models, ed. Jill Berk Jiminez and Joanna Banham (London: Fitzroy Dearborn, 2001), 197–200; and Margaret F. MacDonald, “Maud Franklin and the ‘Charming Little Swaggerers,’” in Margaret F. MacDonald, Susan Grace Galassi, Aileen Ribeiro, and Patricia de Montfort, Whistler, Women, and Fashion, exh. cat. (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 2003), 134–55.

Théodore Duret, quoted in Pennell and Pennell, The Whistler Journal, 164. Whistler also attested to Franklin’s appealing qualities in a letter to his friend George Lucas, writing, “I need not tell you that she is very charming and that you will be delighted with her.” See Whistler to George Aloysius Lucas, Apr. 16, 1879, repr. in The Correspondence of James McNeill Whistler, 1855–1903, ed. Margaret F. MacDonald, Patricia de Montfort, and Nigel Thorp, online edition (Glasgow, UK: University of Glasgow, 2003–10), hereafter GUW, no. 09201.

For further discussion of the ways Whistler exploited this pose in his artwork, see Martha Tedeschi and Britt Salveson, “Early Experiments: Images of Maud Franklin,” “Songs on Stone: James McNeill Whistler and the Art of Lithography,” special issue, Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies 24, no. 1 (1998): 22–31.

MacDonald, “Maud Franklin and the ‘Charming Little Swaggerers,’” 142.

Franklin exhibited three works as “Clifton Lin” at the Grosvenor Gallery in 1884; see Christopher Newall, The Grosvenor Gallery Exhibitions: Change and Continuity in the Victorian Art World (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1995), 97. For a full list of works exhibited by Franklin at the Society of British Artists (which became the Royal Society of British Artists in 1887 under Whistler’s leadership) between 1884 and 1888, see Jane Johnson, Works Exhibited at the Royal Society for British Artists, 1824–1893, and the New English Art Club, 1888–1917 (Woodbridge, Suffolk: Antique Collectors’ Club, 1975), 288. See also MacDonald, “Maud Franklin,” 26n40.

See Pennell and Pennell, The Whistler Journal, 167. For the known details of Franklin’s life, see esp. MacDonald, “Maud Franklin”; MacDonald, “Franklin, Maud (British, 1857–c. 1941),” in Dictionary of Artists’ Models; and “Maud Franklin,” in MacDonald and Petri.

Evidence of this ownership history is provided by a clipping in the Witt Library at the Courtauld Institute of Art related to the drawing’s sale through E. Parsons, a London dealer, in 1924. Photocopy in curatorial object files, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. See also MacDonald (1995), 338–39 (cat. 896). As MacDonald notes, Hanson may well have been responsible for identifying the model in the drawing as Maud Franklin.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 26 Portrait of Miss Maud Franklin, 1883/88.

fig. 26.1 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Maud, Standing, 1876–78. Etching and drypoint with foul biting in black ink on ivory laid paper; 22.7 × 15.2 cm (8 5/16 × 6 in.) (plate); 27.8 × 18.6 cm (10 15/16 × 7 5/16 in.) (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, bequest of Arthur MacDougall Wood, through the generosity of Pauline Wood Egan and Arthur M. Wood, Jr., 2007.145.

fig. 26.2 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). The Toilet, 1878. Lithotint with scraping and incising, on a prepared half-tint ground, in black on cream wove paper; 26 × 16.4 cm (10 1/4 × 6 7/16 in.) (image); 27.9 × 17.7 cm (11 × 7 in.) (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.531.

fig. 26.3 Photograph of Maud Franklin, c. late 1870s (?). Library of Congress, Washington, DC, Pennell Collection, LC-J2-10.

fig. 26.4 Fashion plate by Leon Sault from The Young Ladies’ Journal, 1884. Engraving on paper; 61 × 40.3 cm (24 × 15 7/8 in.). Auckland War Memorial Museum Tāmaki Paenga Hira, EPH-PT-13-17.

</section>
